unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Critical Value in a Slope $t$-Interval: Height, Weight
question_text:
A statistician wanted to construct a $95\%$ confidence interval for the population slope between height (in inches) and weight (in pounds) of his co-workers. He made height the explanatory (independent) variable and weight the response (dependent) variable.
He selected a random sample of $30$ people from work and asked them to list their height and weight. After seeing his conditions were satisfied, he constructed the interval.
Which of the following would he use for the critical value?
solution:
The critical value (t∗), when calculating a slope t-interval, has degrees of freedom n−2, where n is the sample size. In this case, the degrees of freedom is: 30−2=28.

On the t-distribution chart, find where 95% confidence and 28 degrees of freedom intersect.

Explanation of Distractors Choice 'A' is incorrect as this is the critical value for a z-interval of 95% confidence. Choice 'B' is incorrect as this would be the critical value for 32 degrees of freedom and 95% confidence. Choice 'C' is incorrect as this would be the critical value for 30 degrees of freedom and 95% confidence. Choice 'D' is incorrect as this would be the critical value for 29 degrees of freedom and 95% confidence.
